awd_titl_txt: Interactive Virtual Laboratory: Using Renewable Energy Experiments to Enhance Student Engagement in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
By the year 2050, it is estimated that Earth's population will rise to nine billion. The accompanying increased demand for energy requires that sources other than fossil fuels (currently about 86% of the world's energy) be found. There is growing interest in utilizing renewable energy sources such as solar and wind power for clean production of electric power. The overall goal of the project is to significantly increase the number of college graduates with renewable energy and power engineering knowledge and skills in order to ensure a well-prepared US workforce for the future. The objectives are 1) to develop a virtual laboratory for studying distributed power generation systems; 2) to create innovative teaching materials for the virtual laboratory platform; and 3) to engage college students in the mentoring of high school students on renewable energy technologies. The virtual laboratory will be interactive and engaging to stimulate students' interest in STEM. 

The proposed virtual laboratory and prototype smart grid will integrate cutting-edge power systems research by the PIs with a modern power systems educational curriculum. It will greatly improve the capacity and effectiveness to train students in the renewable energy field. The curricular enhancements and new learning materials will focus on authentic problems in renewable energy. An internet portal will be constructed to permit college and pre-college students to experiment with a distributed power generation system and collect data for engineering activities. By graphing and analyzing the data, students will acquire insight on the relative advantages of different configurations of the smart grid. The research questions to be investigated will procure answers that will result in the generation of useful knowledge about the impact of renewable energy interactive virtual labs on college students and their high school mentees. The virtual laboratory will also provide the opportunity to network with other educational institutions as well as a convenient platform for students and faculty to combine teaching and research activities on renewable energy.

por.por_cntn:
Due to the rapid growth of renewable energy technology such as solar and wind power, the nation will have a shortage of skilled power engineers. This project aimed to increase the number of college graduates with renewable energy and power engineering knowledge and skills in order to create a sufficient workforce for the future by 1) developing a virtual laboratory for a distributed power generation system; 2) creating innovative teaching materials including demonstrations, hands-on experiments, and course modules using the virtual laboratory and a prototype solar microgrid; and 3) engaging college students in the mentoring of high school students on renewable energy technologies.

Intellectual Merits:

This project built an internet portal in which students can experiment with distributed power generation system, and collect data for their engineering activities. Networking and information technology were used to create the virtual laboratory. The virtual laboratory is interactive and engaged the students to increase their interest in STEM learning. A laboratory scale solar microgrid with wireless data acquisition was also designed and built. The prototype created a planform to integrate demonstrations and experiments for problem-based learning.

The virtual laboratory and prototype solar microgrid integrated the cutting-edge research by the PIs with educational curriculum. It improved the capacity and effectiveness to train students in renewable energy. The virtual laboratory has scalable architecture to ensure the system can be expanded by adding more experiments. Experiments and activities were developed for the virtual laboratory to engage college students and faculty to research renewable energy technology and investigate how these can solve environmental and societal issues. The teaching materials were used for engineering technology courses, and outreach program for high school students.

Broader Impact:

This project addressed the need for a qualified workforce in the field of renewable energy by directly benefiting 100 undergraduate students in the Department of Engineering Technology and approximately 100 high school students. The curricular enhancements and new learning materials focused on authentic problems in renewable energy. The virtual laboratory provided the opportunity to network with other educational institutions and creates the platform for students and faculty to combine learning, teaching, and research on renewable energy. The progressive approach used in building content knowledge throughout the curriculum prepared graduates with strong content and research skills needed to advance the field of renewable energy, thus providing professionals with the skills needed to keep the U.S. competitive globally.

The project attracted students, especially women and under-represented groups, into engineering technology, through outreach activities, open houses, lab tours and seminars. The project has a broad impact on engineering technology education by providing a national model for recruitment and retention of renewable energy technology and improve student learning. The results of the project were disseminated in journal publications, conference presentations, newsletters, and its webpage (https://renewablelab.niu.edu/).

Presentation

Guo, L. Interactive Virtual Laboratory for Renewable Energy, 2021 STEM For All Video Showcase https://stemforall2021.videohall.com/presentations/2001

Publication

Guo, L. and Kors, J., Jr. (2021) Design of a Laboratory Scale Solar Microgrid Cyber-Physical System for Education. Electronics, vol. 10, no. 13.

Guo, L. and Abdul, N.M.M. (2021) Design and Evaluation of Fuzzy Adaptive Particle Swarm Optimization Based Maximum Power Point Tracking on Photovoltaic System Under Partial Shading Conditions. Frontiers in Energy Research, vol. 9.

Guo, L., Vengalil, M., Abdul, N. M. M., and Wang, K. (2022) Design and implementation of a virtual laboratory for renewable energy based microgrid. Computer Applications in Engineering Education, vol. 30, no. 2, pp.349-361. 

Guo, L., Abdul, N. M. M., Vengalil, M., Wang, K. and Santuzzi, A. (2022) “Engaging Renewable Energy Education Using a Web-Based Interactive Microgrid Virtual Laboratory,” IEEE Access, vol. 10, pp. 60972-60984.
